Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Fundamental Science Underpinning Stretchable Lithium Ion Batteries

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objectives of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award are to (a) experimentally and computationally elucidate the fundamental mechanisms underpinning ion conductivity and other relevant thermo-mechanical properties in next generation polymer nanocomposite electrolytes, and (b) discover the effect of mechanical stresses and strains on electrochemical performance and potential coupling effects in flexible and stretchable lithium ion batteries. Fundamental understanding of electrochemical and mechanical properties in stretchable PNEs and Li ion batteries will pave the way for the realization of many tantalizing applications such as intelligent electronic textiles, rollable computers, electronic eyes among others.

Outreach efforts will aim to (a) educate general public and students of all levels on science and engineering, with specific emphasis on energy storage and (b) increase interest and participation in engineering among minorities and women. Educational outreach will be accomplished through dissemination of energy-science related issues by occasionally hosting a radio show (with an audience exceeding 50,000 listeners), participation in the international sustainable world energy engineering environment project to motivate high school students towards energy research and collaboration with an ongoing NSF GK12 program at UH to target local schools with significant Hispanic and African-American populations. New graduate and undergraduate courses themed around energy with significant hands-on component will be developed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The impetus towards flexible and stretchable electronics, including touch-screens and wearable sensors, has galvanized research in flexible and stretchable energy storage devices. Lithium ion batteries (LIBs), based on their superior attributes including high energy density and efficiency, are the leading candidates for transformation into flexible and stretchable thin-film batteries. In this 5-year NSF funded research program, we investigated flexible and stretchable lithium ion batteries, and specifically, explored materials and battery designs, fabrication methodologies, and comprehensive characterization and testing through both experiments and theoretical/computational modeling.

The flammable organic liquid electrolyte, commonly used in traditional batteries, was replaced with solid polymer electrolyte, specifically, polyethylene oxide (PEO), to enable a safer, more stable and mechanically flexible (bendable) battery. Although polymer electrolytes offer many advantages, one of their main drawbacks is their lower ion conductivity compared to that of conventional liquid electrolytes. Therefore, the polymer electrolyte properties were improved through the design and investigation of novel nanocomposite materials. We added small percentage of graphene oxide (GO) nanosheets to PEO and discovered up to 2 orders of magnitude increase in ion conductivity, and more importantly, a noticeable enhancement in battery performance and capacity.   Theoretical and computational modeling including molecular dynamics (MD) simulation were conducted to provide fundamental insight on the effect of nanosized filler on ion diffusion in polymer electrolyte.

Based on the GO-PEO polymer nanocomposite electrolyte, flexible and bendable lithium ion batteries were fabricated. The battery performance under mechanical bending was also evaluated. The battery showed higher capacity during mechanical bending. Further investigation through mechanics based modeling and experiments revealed that contact pressure and contact conductance increase during bending, leading to an enhanced battery performance. The effect of bending cycles on the flexible battery was also investigated demonstrating good voltage retention over many thousands of bending cycles.

A fundamental area related to stretchable batteries that is relatively unexplored and not well understood, is the effect of stretching on polymer electrolyte ion conductivity.  Novel in situ experiments were designed and carried out to measure ion conductivity of polymer electrolyte film at various tensile strains. At smaller stretching strains a linear increasing trend in ion conductivity was observed. At larger tensile strains, this trend transitioned to an exponential behavior. Mechanics based modeling was used to explain the effects of stretching on ion conductivity at both small and large strains. 

Using solid polymer electrolyte, various configurations of lithium ion batteries were designed and fabricated including spiral stretchable batteries, sliding electrode stretchable batteries, and fabric-based stretchable batteries. Spiral batteries can also be stretched out-of-plane (z-axis). The spiral battery shows high voltage retention over many thousands of stretching cycles.  We also designed, fabricated and tested sliding electrodes, stretchable electrolyte battery. Another type of stretchable battery is fabric-based. We created stretchable electrodes based on stretchable fabrics subjected to full battery and electrode characterization.

Interfaces in flexible and stretchable batteries, especially solid-to-solid, are critical areas that can significantly affect the performance of the battery. We explored various mechanisms to enhance the interfaces including the addition of soy-based protein-rich biomaterial to the battery. This resulted in enhancement of the interface conductance, and battery performance.

The outcomes of this 5-year research program include several publications, patents, public radio episodes, conference presentations, and training of future engineers, scientists and researchers including women and minorities in STEM field. This research paves the way toward advancing science and technology, specifically, the realization of flexible and stretchable batteries for many tantalizing applications such as wearable medical devices, organ implants, structural batteries, and smart suits and clothing.
